channel.title: Chip programmer
channel.description:
I am looking for the cheapest chip programmer I can buy that will program the bare minimum of AT29C256 (EEPROM), and 27C256 (EPROM). In case you are wondering why I need to be able to do this:
http://www.thirdgen.org/promintro
However it points to a programmer that is $249, which is out of my budget range, I am trying to keep the whole business under $200 (special cable, programmer, PROM, (and UV eraser if I can't go with the EEPROM) Does that seem feasible?
If anyone can help me out, I'd appreciate it.

item.title: Chip programmer
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

Moparisthebest, have you found one yet? If not, I think you could of made your own programmer and the software for it pictures please when you do it!

Read full topic

item.title: Chip programmer
item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx
item.description:
@peterbjornx wrote:

newbiehacker:

sorry peterbjornx, but that is the worst explained idea in history, please elaborate how exactly counters connected to a parallel port would allow you to flash an EPROM chip

Like the data bus on the parralel port is connected to the Q0…7 I/O’s on the chip, something needs to supply adresses, so you could hook up a couple of interconnected counters to the address lines and drive it by one of the status lines on the parport, so like

JAVA example

for (int i = 0; i < data.length;i++){
parport.resetBit(SOME_STATUS_LINE2);//#CE low, enable chip
parport.setByte(data);
parport.setBit(SOME_STATUS_LINE2);//#CE high, disable chip
parport.setBit(SOME_STATUS_LINE);//addr++
}

Read full topic

item.title: Chip programmer
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:11, topic:290106”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=383487.msg2924147#msg2924147 date=1250910327]

Not to mention I really want a USB chip burner so that I can burn the chips with a laptop while sitting in the truck, without having to carry it to my desktop all the time.

Make a Serial Cable with a breadboard, using the chip’s correct pin out and get a USB->Serial adapter. Or a PCMIA serial port card.
[/quote]

And then I just have to write my own driver and flashing program, right?

I’d rather buy a freaking chip programmer, damn it! :P[/quote]
No, there are lots of programs for reading off and writing to chips, you just need to have it made with the correct pins.

Read full topic

I’d rather buy a freaking chip programmer, damn it! :P[/quote]

If you wrote your own driver and flashing program, you could release it open sauce, damn it!

item.title: Chip programmer
item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx
item.description:
@peterbjornx wrote:

why not build your own using some basic logic ics(counters) and a PC parralel port, like databus (D0…7) to the Q0…7 pins of the EPROM, and one of the signal lines to counter 1, counter 1 carry to counter 2 and there outputs to the A0…15 or so (different per chip)

Read full topic

item.title: Chip programmer
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

If you look at the chip’s schematics, and find the TX/RX Gnd and +ve input, you could make a serial cable that will work, you just need a few resistors, a battery/DC transformer, an audio jack and audio->Serial cable then get the PC based programming editor.

Read full topic

item.title: Chip programmer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

A chip programmer is a physical object you attach to your computer, put a blank chip in, and burn a program to it. Downloading that would be like downloading a printer.

So does anyone do this kind of stuff?

Read full topic
